title: 105_hr4218
content: The Act may be cited as the "Section 8 Housing Improvement Act" and includes a limitation on the use of assistance by area. The United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to allow public housing agencies to limit the number of families using assistance to rent a dwelling unit within a defined area. The United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to allow public housing agencies to limit the number of families renting a dwelling unit in a defined area to preserve property value, resident safety, and the area's unique character. The limitation cannot restrict more families than necessary for these purposes. SEC. 3. NEIGHBORHOOD REVIEW COMMITTEES. The United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to include a new subsection (m) requiring public housing agencies to establish neighborhood review committees consisting of 3-6 individuals, with at least 3 not receiving housing assistance. The United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to require public housing agencies to establish neighborhood review committees consisting of residents to advise on enforcement of laws governing rental assistance programs. The United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to allow public housing agencies to access various records and information regarding household members receiving tenant-based assistance, including criminal records, police reports, and references from past landlords. The United States Housing Act of 1937 amendment allows public housing agencies to access records related to household members receiving tenant-based assistance, including criminal records, civil actions, judgments, settlements, and other relevant information. This applies to all household members receiving assistance, and applicants must be informed of their confidentiality rights. Additionally, agencies can access records regarding landlords. The United States Housing Act of 1937 amendment allows public housing agencies to access records related to landlords, including criminal records, police reports, violations of housing laws, and complaints filed. The United States Housing Act of 1937 amendment allows public housing agencies to access records related to landlords, including complaints, grievances, actions filed by tenants, judgments, settlements, and penalties for unauthorized disclosure of information. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will issue regulations within 12 months of the enactment of the Act to enforce the amendment. Penalties for unauthorized disclosure of information include imprisonment for up to one year and a fine of up to $10,000. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT OF HOUSING QUALITY STANDARDS. Enforcement of Housing Quality Standards: Amends Section 8 of the United States Housing Act to require action if a dwelling unit fails to comply with housing quality standards. The public housing agency must notify the Secretary, tenant, and owner of noncompliance and the required actions. During noncompliance, assistance amounts will be withheld by the agency and the Secretary for the unit. The withheld amounts will be released to the owner once the noncompliance is corrected. The owner cannot terminate a tenant's lease due to the withholding of assistance. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will issue regulations to enforce the amendment within 12 months of the enactment of the Act. The amendment applies to dwelling units with housing assistance contracts entered into or renewed after the implementation of the regulations.
